sentence: Facial recognition is an emerging technology that spurs the imagination like no other.
Developers of the technology, on the one hand, promise that it will improve security, healthcare, marketing, shopping experiences, and more.
Developers of the technology, on the one hand, promise that it will improve security, healthcare, marketing, shopping experiences, and more.

Although facial recognition has many application domains and purposes, the focus here lies on the use of facial recognition in stores and restaurants to offer customers personalized services, such as tailored advertisements, discounts, or recommendations.
I discuss facial recognition technology in a broad sense, including the identification of individuals as well as the recognition of certain characteristics (e.g.
That is, they can steer technology development, research funding and societal adoption of a technology.
That is, they can steer technology development, research funding and societal adoption of a technology.

Moreover, promises and expectations raised by authoritative sources like tech companies or established media have the power to shape the expectations and attitude of average citizens regarding a technology.

Because of the powerful role that expectations play, ethicists should not merely question under what conditions a given technology is desirable, but also assess whether the existing expectations about it are plausible (Lucivero et al.

An assessment of the plausibility of expectations enables ethicists to anticipate potential ethical implications more accurately and critically, which in turn makes their ethical evaluation of the given emerging technology more informed and pertinent.
The aim of this case study is to assess the plausibility of promises and expectations regarding facial recognition technology.
The focus lies on the use of facial recognition for personalization purposes, which mainly applies to the retail and hospitality industry.

This specific focus on the use of facial recognition for personalization is relevant to the work done in WP2 (on the ethics of personalization) and interesting because facial recognition is most often discussed with regards to its security applications.
The structure of this case study is as follows.

First I sketch the optimistic promises of technology developers, based on the promises and descriptions provided on the websites of three companies that offer facial recognition technology for businesses (2.1).

First I sketch the optimistic promises of technology developers, based on the promises and descriptions provided on the websites of three companies that offer facial recognition technology for businesses (2.1).
Feasibility refers to claims made about the technology’s future functionalities.
Use or usability entails, among other things, the way in which the technology is expected to be applied or integrated in society.
Use or usability entails, among other things, the way in which the technology is expected to be applied or integrated in society.
A useful starting point for sketching the most promising, yet informed, expectations regarding facial recognition is to look at the companies that develop and sell the technology.

The present discussion is based on the description of facial recognition products for business intelligence as found on the websites of three different companies – namely the Swedish company Axis Communications (Sorri, 2017; Retail, n.d.); the Russian NTechLab’s facial recognition solutions called FindFace (Face Recognition for Retail, n.d.); and Rekognition, the video analytics technology offered by the well-known American company Amazon (Amazon Rekognition, n.d.; AWS Admin, 2019).
A first function of facial recognition technology is the recognition of customers’ identities on the basis of their face.
Personalized adds can either be sent via text or email or displayed on screens in a store or restaurant.
A second use of facial recognition for personalization is through the recognition not of people’s identities, but their individual characteristics.
It is suggested that facial recognition technology will be able to make accurate inferences about customers’ age, gender and sentiment, in a split second.

Because of its potential to bring personalization from the online sphere into offline, real-life shops and restaurants, facial recognition is described as a “powerful business intelligence tool” (Retail, n.d.).

Not only would facial recognition help to improve sales and reduce costs (Face Recognition for Retail, n.d.), it is also suggested that it betters the lives of customers by improving services and user experiences – for example by offering people products and services they really need, or by speeding up services because “today you can’t make people wait” (Face Recognition for Retail, n.d.).

Not only would facial recognition help to improve sales and reduce costs (Face Recognition for Retail, n.d.), it is also suggested that it betters the lives of customers by improving services and user experiences – for example by offering people products and services they really need, or by speeding up services because “today you can’t make people wait” (Face Recognition for Retail, n.d.).
The technology is supposed to making a service or shopping experience joyful and frictionless.
It is only obvious that technology developers sell their products with attractive promises and expectations.
For the purposes of the present case study I have specifically searched for dystopic promises and expectations about the use of facial recognition for personalization.

In these movies, however, the technology is mainly used to recognize individuals and grant them access to certain spaces or documents, or to recognize criminals or suspects either from a distance or in video footage.
The only found example of the use of facial recognition for personalization purposes is in the 2002 movie Minority Report, which is set in the United States of 2054.

If citizens only encounter dystopic images in which facial recognition would threaten their freedom, this may instill in them a fear or suspicion about the technology and, consequently, impact their attitude towards it when they are confronted with facial recognition applications in real life.

If citizens only encounter dystopic images in which facial recognition would threaten their freedom, this may instill in them a fear or suspicion about the technology and, consequently, impact their attitude towards it when they are confronted with facial recognition applications in real life.

In other words, facial recognition might barely be used for personalization purposes in science fiction, but the dystopic imaginaries in which facial recognition is used for security or surveillance purposes in such movies and novels can also affect individuals’ expectations or acceptation of the technology when it emerges in real life stores and restaurants.
The technology displayed in the movie was not based on wild guesses, an expert panel was consulted to give an informed prediction of the technology used in society in the year 2054.
The technology displayed in the movie was not based on wild guesses, an expert panel was consulted to give an informed prediction of the technology used in society in the year 2054.

Ethicists should therefore not use science fiction movies and novels as their core input for the evaluation of emerging technologies, but merely as a helpful tool for the anticipation and assessment of emerging technologies.

Ethicists should therefore not use science fiction movies and novels as their core input for the evaluation of emerging technologies, but merely as a helpful tool for the anticipation and assessment of emerging technologies.

Sci-fi can be helpful to technology assessment because it can point out possible uses or implications and because it has the power to shape individuals’ view on a technology, even if it was never meant as a realistic depiction thereof.

Some of the main concerns about the technology have to do with its present and potential uses by oppressive regimes, its implications for privacy, and the bias in facial recognition systems that can lead to discriminatory outcomes.

However, similar to the appearance of the technology in science fiction, we see that the focus of concern and attention in the media lies with the use of facial recognition by governments and for surveillance, rather than the use by companies for personalization.

In most cases these concerns have little to do with the use of facial recognition as a business intelligence tool.
It also describes the personalized food recommendations as possibly being “patronizingly gendered” and a privacy-convenience trade-off.

An example of an article focusing on facial recognition for personalization is a 2017 article in the Guardian, which describes the use of facial recognition to personalize menu displays in KFC restaurants in China.
Popular media sources about the use of facial recognition for law enforcement are much more dystopic in their discussion of the technology.

Here it is pointed out, amongst other things, that facial recognition “is a technology of control that is symptomatic of the state’s mistrust of its citizens”; that “we can no longer do anything in public without the state knowing about it”; and that it implies that “private companies and law enforcement agencies are sharing our images to build watchlists of potential suspects without our knowledge or consent”, which is again described as a threat to society and civil liberties (Schippers, 2019).

The website suggests that facial recognition is a dangerous technology that will be used not to keep us safe (as security companies that sell facial recognition promise), but to exercise control over us.
Hence, it threatens our liberty and society at large.
Moreover, it is suggested that the technology’s harms “far outweigh any potential benefits”.
Another example of the often dystopic views found in popular media is an article entitled Facial Recognition: 10 reasons you should be worried about the technology.

25.2.3	Utopia or dystopia?
The promises and expectations about the possibilities, uses and value of facial recognition technology in the next 5 to 10 years go in two opposite directions.

However, we found that these sources focus heavily on the use of facial recognition by security and law enforcement and thereby overlook the use of facial recognition for personalization purposes, by businesses.

However, we found that these sources focus heavily on the use of facial recognition by security and law enforcement and thereby overlook the use of facial recognition for personalization purposes, by businesses.

However, we found that these sources focus heavily on the use of facial recognition by security and law enforcement and thereby overlook the use of facial recognition for personalization purposes, by businesses.

However, we found that these sources focus heavily on the use of facial recognition by security and law enforcement and thereby overlook the use of facial recognition for personalization purposes, by businesses.

Therefore we cannot really conclude that there are dystopic expectations out there when it comes to facial recognition for personalization – which is the technology that is investigated in this case study.

The question then is whether the lack of attention for facial recognition as a personalization tool in dystopic technological imaginaries signifies a blind spot of technology pessimists, or simply implies that such uses of facial recognition are not that worrisome.

To assess the plausibility of the expectations raised about facial recognition, I first analyze the feasibility of these expectations – more specifically, whether the expected functioning of the technology is technically and legally feasible.

In this section I will look at two claims made about the functioning of facial recognition for personalization: 1) that it is (in)accurate and 2) that it can gather and use information about individuals’ identity, age, gender and mood.
Companies that offer facial recognition technology for business intelligence promise it will work in real-time (i.e.

Popular media, on the other hand, is more skeptical about the technology’s accuracy, due to recent findings that facial recognition systems work much better on White males than on White women or people with other ethnicities.

First of all, when the training data on which recognition models are trained are not sufficiently inclusive, the model will perform worse on those people whose gender or ethnicity was not well represented in the training data.

First of all, when the training data on which recognition models are trained are not sufficiently inclusive, the model will perform worse on those people whose gender or ethnicity was not well represented in the training data.
This source of inaccuracy can be expected to be overcome in the future, by ensuring that training data are inclusive.

First of all, when the training data on which recognition models are trained are not sufficiently inclusive, the model will perform worse on those people whose gender or ethnicity was not well represented in the training data.

First of all, when the training data on which recognition models are trained are not sufficiently inclusive, the model will perform worse on those people whose gender or ethnicity was not well represented in the training data.
This source of inaccuracy can be expected to be overcome in the future, by ensuring that training data are inclusive.
Hence, the claim of accuracy might not be valid now, but it is a feasible expectation that facial recognition will be highly accurate in all circumstances in the future.
Even with today’s state of facial recognition technology, the former is technically possible.
To recognize regular customers stores are required to keep a database with their pictures, which can be a breach with current or future data protection laws.

It is questionable whether the technology will ever be able to deal with those who do not fit these stereotypes or not even identify with a binary gender model at all.
Finally, some scientists question whether mood or emotion recognition on the basis of one’s facial features will ever be technically feasible (Barret et al., 2019).
Like emotion recognition, these claims have no solid scientific basis – they resemble pseudo sciences like physiognomy and phrenology.
To assess the plausibility of expectations regarding the use of a technology, we have to consider the adoption of the technology by users as well as its integration into existing practices.
To assess the plausibility of expectations regarding the use of a technology, we have to consider the adoption of the technology by users as well as its integration into existing practices.
A technology might not be very usable to the average individual because it is too complicated or too expensive.
Another reason a technology turns out to be unusable is that the environment in which it will be used undergoes unforeseen changes.
But expectations about use might also be off in the sense that users are not as interested or likely to adopt the technology as expected.
But expectations about use might also be off in the sense that users are not as interested or likely to adopt the technology as expected.
The optimistic expectations about facial recognition mention a few aspects regarding use.
If these facial recognition systems are indeed easy to use, this increases the likelihood that an average store or restaurant owner will adopt the product.
If these facial recognition systems are indeed easy to use, this increases the likelihood that an average store or restaurant owner will adopt the product.

Secondly, the discussed companies mention three main uses of facial recognition for business intelligence: 1) making stores more efficient and speeding up the shopping process, 2) improving the customer experience, and 3) increasing sales by offering special treatment to certain customers (e.g.

The dystopic expectations, on the other hand, suggest that facial recognition will be used to exercise control over individuals and that companies could create a watchlist of suspicious people and share this with governments.
With the insights gained from facial analysis, companies can indeed control individuals, in the sense that it increases their power to manipulate or influence consumer behavior.
It is important to add, however, that companies will not adopt the technology for the sake of exercising control, but simply to increase their profit.
The plausibility of the expectation that companies will share information with governments is most of all dependent on legal restrictions in place in the country of use.
The plausibility of the expectation that companies will share information with governments is most of all dependent on legal restrictions in place in the country of use.
Becoming aware of the values inherent to technology expectations enables an ethicist to give a more objective evaluation of an emerging technology.
Becoming aware of the values inherent to technology expectations enables an ethicist to give a more objective evaluation of an emerging technology.
Making as much profit as possible can be understood as an economic or capitalist value, which drives this emerging technology.
The use of personalization should, first of all, make a shopping experience faster.
It is even claimed that the technology will improve the lives of customers.

When assessing these expectations we should ask ourselves whether customers will indeed enjoy automated personalized treatment and whether it’s impact will be so significant that it can be seen as improving their lives, or whether all these promises are just nice words to cover up the fact that people’s behavior is manipulated and their privacy compromised for the sake of profit.
Tom Cruise’s character John Anderton is shown ads to have a Guinness or go on a holiday, implying that he could use a break.
John appears to be annoyed by it rather than enjoying the convenience or meaningfulness of personalized marketing.
In popular media, the potential convenience of the use of facial recognition for personalization is recognized, but contrasted with the loss of privacy and threat to civil liberties.

The values embedded in these rather dystopic expectations of facial recognition are privacy, consent and democracy – which are thought of as outweighing any possible convenience the technology might bring.

The values embedded in these rather dystopic expectations of facial recognition are privacy, consent and democracy – which are thought of as outweighing any possible convenience the technology might bring.

The values embedded in these rather dystopic expectations of facial recognition are privacy, consent and democracy – which are thought of as outweighing any possible convenience the technology might bring.

To assess the plausibility of these expectations, we should first critically question or investigate the weight citizens generally ascribe to convenience, on the one hand, and values like privacy, consent and democracy, on the other hand.

In addition, it should be researched how likely it is that the use of facial recognition in stores and restaurants will indeed compromise privacy, democracy and our civil liberties, and how heavy these effects really are.

Such an assessment is a valuable basis for the anticipation and ethical evaluation of emerging technologies like facial recognition (Lucivero et al., 2011; Lucivero, 2016).
I analyzed positive expectations raised by companies who develop and sell this technology, and negative expectations found in science fiction movies and regular media.
Regarding some specific expectations, further empirical or legal research would be required to adequately assess their plausibility.

This is for example the case for the dystopic claim that companies will share data with governments to facilitate citizen watchlists (there might be legal restrictions that prevent this from happening), or the promise that facial recognition technology will be highly accurate on all demographics (which might not be technically feasible).

Pessimistic expectations of facial recognition tend to overlook its potential for business intelligence altogether.
Both science fiction and media focus excessively on the use of facial recognition by law enforcement.

However, on the basis of this modest assessment I can conclude that optimistic expectations of facial recognition as a business intelligence tool tend to overstate the desirability of the technology and overestimate the level of personalization that can be offered on the basis of age, gender and mood recognition.

As a result, the average non tech savvy individual might only associate the technology with governmental surveillance and oppression, when encountering facial recognition in their local supermarket or favorite fast food restaurant.

Furthermore, the fact that expectations about the use of facial recognition for personalization, specifically, are one-sidedly positive, can cause the technology to become embedded in society without sufficient consideration for its potential negative implications.
